title: Understanding Absolute References
text: In Excel, an absolute reference is a way to keep a cell reference constant when copying a formula to another cell. This is done by adding a dollar sign ($) before the column letter and row number. For example, $H$1.

title: Moving Formulas Without Changing Addresses
text: When you copy a formula in Excel, the cell references within the formula may change based on the new location. Using absolute references ensures the original cell addresses are maintained.

title: Select Absolute Reference in Reference Panel
text: The option to "select absolute reference in the reference panel" is not a feature in Excel for making formulas constant. Excel requires the use of the '$' symbol in formulas to create absolute references.

title: Copying Formulas vs Numeric Values
text: Copying a formula copies both the formula and its format, while copying a numeric value only copies the displayed number, not any underlying formulas. Therefore, the statement "You cannot copy a formula, only numeric values" is incorrect.

title: Freeze Pane Function
text: The 'freeze pane' option in Excel is used to keep certain rows or columns visible while scrolling through the rest of the spreadsheet. It does not affect the cell references in formulas.

title: Turning a Formula into an Absolute Reference
text: To maintain the formula $$=H1+H8$$ as constant even after copying, change it to =$H1+$H8, where the $ signs ensure the reference remains unchanged regardless of where it is pasted.
